content: The "Parkinson's Research Act of 1997" aims to expand federal investment in Parkinson's research and improve coordination among NIH institutes. It also seeks to enhance care and assistance for individuals with Parkinson's and their caregivers. The "Parkinson's Research Act of 1997" expands federal investment in Parkinson's research under the Public Health Service Act. The "Parkinson's Research Act of 1997" expands federal investment in Parkinson's research under the Public Health Service Act. The Director of NIH shall establish a program for research and training on Parkinson's disease, coordinating with national research institutes and holding research planning conferences every two years. The "Parkinson's Research Act of 1997" mandates research planning conferences every two years to coordinate Parkinson's research efforts. Additionally, Core Center Grants are awarded by the Director of NIH to promote innovative research at Morris K. Udall Research Centers. The Director of NIH awards Core Center Grants to establish Morris K. Udall Centers for Research on Parkinson's Disease, encouraging innovative multidisciplinary research and training. Each center funded under these grants must meet specific requirements related to Parkinson's. The Morris K. Udall Center for Research on Parkinson's Disease is awarded grants by the Director of NIH to conduct basic and clinical research on Parkinson's. The centers must use the facilities of a single institution or a consortium of cooperating institutions and meet qualifications set by the NIH Director. The Morris K. Udall Center for Research on Parkinson's Disease conducts basic and clinical research on Parkinson's. The center may also provide training programs, information, and continuing education to health professionals. The Morris K. Udall Center for Research on Parkinson's Disease conducts programs for information dissemination to health professionals and the public, as well as establishing a nationwide data system for Parkinson's patients. The Morris K. Udall Center for Research on Parkinson's Disease aims to establish a nationwide data system derived from patient populations with Parkinson's and create a Parkinson's Disease Information Clearinghouse to enhance understanding of the disease. The Morris K. Udall Center for Research on Parkinson's Disease aims to enhance knowledge and understanding of Parkinson's disease through a national education program and providing stipends for scientists and health professionals in training programs. The Morris K. Udall Center for Research on Parkinson's Disease provides stipends for scientists and health professionals in training programs for a duration of up to five years, extendable for additional periods upon review by a scientific peer group. The Director of NIH will establish a grant program to support researchers in Parkinson's disease research with a proven track record of excellence and innovation. Grants will be available for up to 5 years, extendable upon recommendation by a peer review group. The NIH will establish a grant program for Parkinson's research, with grants available for up to 5 years. $100,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1998, with additional funding for 1999 and 2000. No funds from the Public Health Service can be used for research under this program. The NIH will establish a grant program for Parkinson's research with grants available for up to 5 years. $100,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1998, with additional funding for fiscal years 1999 and 2000. No funds from the Public Health Service can be used for research that involves human fetal tissue obtained from a living or dead human embryo or fetus during or after an induced abortion, except for tissue obtained from a spontaneous abortion or an ectopic pregnancy.
